title: AGENTS.md
text: Notes added markdown list items. like Keep notes short concrete (commit SHA + impact + risk). eb493fd: ordered_sequence key APIs aligned around key/from_key/to_key, extract_key renamed pop_key, missing-key reads non-throwing (peek_key(..., if_missing=...), pop_key() null-returns miss). Risk: callers relying previous argument names/error behavior need updates. eb493fd: removed delete_one/delete_all; peek_key() pop_key() now support = "first"|"" "" operates full duplicate-key runs returns ordered slice. Risk: code using deleted functions assuming pop_key() always pops one element must migrate. eb493fd: pop_front()/pop_back() now return element (value) plus rest; tests/docs/vignette updated. Risk: callers using $value must switch $element. eb493fd: removed ordered_multiset API/tests dropped package-level set-op generics (union/intersect/setdiff) tied surface. Risk: code importing package methods must migrate explicit sequence operations. eb493fd: hardened C++ monoid/measures field access GC pressure src/ft_cpp.cpp (name lookup fallback monoid subfields; recursive fallback .size/.named_count reads measure names missing). Risk: GC torture remains expensive; pop_key(='') excluded GC-stress assertions keep suite deterministic. eb493fd: ensure_size_monoids() now canonicalizes every monoid spec named list(f, , measure) validates f/measure functions use. Impact: C++ positional fallback remains safe even monoid list names absent; risk: malformed custom MeasureMonoid objects now fail earlier clearer errors. eb493fd: benchmark harness longer references removed ordered_multiset/set-op scenarios; quick/full profiles now target live APIs . Risk: historical OMS benchmark comparisons longer directly reproducible default profiles. eb493fd: quick/full benchmark profiles now include ordered_sequence_insert keep ordered-keyed workload coverage OMS removal; pq_insert_pop remains available custom-scenario. Risk: historical quick/full trend lines one scenario changed. eb493fd: full-profile benchmark sizes reduced high-cost R-backend scenarios (flexseq_tree_from*, split variants, index reads, as_flexseq_only) keep single-scenario runs within ~30s capped. Risk: full-profile values less stress-heavy earlier settings. eb493fd: fixed insert.ordered_sequence() R fallback boundary case (use_cpp=FALSE) avoiding public push_back() guard appending split-left fragments; ordered_sequence_insert benchmarks now execute R backend. Risk: internal append helper path continue preserve ordered wrapping invariants (covered ordered-sequence tests). eb493fd: benchmark coverage now includes additional non-flexseq structure scenarios (ordered_sequence_bounds, pq_insert_pop) quick/full profiles R-safe parameter sizes. Risk: scenario names/default params changed; compare historical runs scenario+params, just run label. eb493fd: added deeper ordered-sequence priority-queue benchmark scenarios (ordered_sequence_range_queries, ordered_sequence_pop_cycle, pq_peek_min_max, pq_pop_min_drain, pq_mixed_ops) improve optimization signal across lookup vs mutation-heavy paths. Risk: broader quick/full profiles increase total run time; use run_scenarios() focused profiling. f300088: interval_index query surface now uses peek_point/peek_overlaps/peek_containing/peek_within plus pop_point/relation pop_*; removed find_* interval query helpers exports/docs/tests. Risk: callers using removed find_* APIs must migrate peek_*/pop_*. f300088: ordered-subclass blocker errors now report concrete subclass names inherited mutation endpoints (c, push_front, push_back, insert_at, [<-, [[<-, $<-) rather hardcoded ordered_sequence. Risk: callers/tests matching exact prior error strings may need updates. 53437c6+local: removed legacy internal ordered merge path (.ft_cpp_oms_set_merge) R wrapper, C registration, C++ implementation, parity/GC test references “ordered merge” remains true across layers. Risk: developer-code invoking removed internal symbol now errors must wait planned clean reimplementation. 53437c6+local: tightened test signal quality (validate_* now asserts invisible TRUE, redundant test-seq-apply monoid case folded one stronger persistence assertion, element tests now assert value-level identity list/data.frame payloads). Risk: stricter tests may fail immediately semantics intentionally change require explicit test updates. Root cause: bare SEXP variables holding newly-allocated R objects (R function calls make_* helpers) invisible R’s GC, scan C++ stack. subsequent R allocation (including Rcpp Function::operator() building call via Rf_lang3) can trigger GC collect temporaries. Pattern 1 — unprotected R function results used args another R function call: e.g. SEXP m = measure(ch); f(acc.get(), m). f() call allocates build LANGSXP executing, collecting m. Fix: Shield<SEXP> m(measure(ch)); f(acc.get(), (SEXP)m). Affected: measures_from_children, measure_sequence, locate_digit_impl_cpp, split_digit_cpp. Pattern 2 — multiple make_* results direct arguments make_deep: e.g. make_deep(make_digit(...), make_empty(...), make_digit(...), monoids). C++ argument eval order implementation-defined; make_* allocates heavily. Fix: Shield result passing. Affected: tree_from_sorted_list_cpp, digit_to_tree_cpp. Pattern 3 — unprotected make_* results List::push_back: push_back reallocates list, can collect unprotected temporary. Fix: Shield push_back. Affected: measured_nodes_cpp. Safe patterns (fix needed): d["prefix"], sm["left"], ms[monoid_name] etc. return pointers existing protected lists — elements kept alive parent objects attribute chain back .Call arguments. Shield<SEXP> ReprotectSEXP usage add_right_cpp, add_left_cpp, viewL_cpp, viewR_cpp already correct. Testing: IMMUTABLES_GC_STRESS=1 gctorture2(1) reliably triggers bugs. Always run GC torture C++ changes touching SEXP temporaries.

title: Consistency Notes: ordered_sequence vs interval_index
text: fapply.ordered_sequence() aligned payload-return (metadata read-). fapply.priority_queue() aligned payload-return (metadata read-). fapply.flexseq() now always preserves/recomputes existing monoids; removed preserve_monoids parameter. Added explicit as_flexseq.ordered_sequence() as_flexseq.interval_index() methods; subtype casts longer fall failing default dispatch. ordered_sequence priority_queue [[/$ reads now return payloads (entry wrappers). Current cross-structure state: fapply methods now use payload-returns. interval_index relation reads now use peek_overlaps / peek_containing / peek_within; removed relation find_* APIs operations. interval_index point APIs now use peek_point / pop_point; removed find_point. interval_index query API hard-replaced find_* peek_* (compatibility aliases). interval_index now blocks peek_front / peek_back / peek_at pop_front / pop_back / pop_at. Ordered-subclass blocker errors now class-generic inherited APIs (c, push_front, push_back, insert_at, replacement indexing), subclasses report concrete class name errors. Removed legacy internal ordered merge primitive (.ft_cpp_oms_set_merge) backend R/C++ bindings parity/GC test coverage; ordered merge remains intentionally unavailable redesign. Test consistency tightened: validate_* assertions now require invisible TRUE, redundant fapply.flexseq monoid-recompute case collapsed, mixed payload tests now assert value-level identity (just types).

title: Consistency Notes: ordered_sequence vs interval_index
text: None currently tracked pair (ordered_sequence vs interval_index).

title: Consistency Notes: ordered_sequence vs interval_index
text: priority_queue remains strict name-[[ reads (positional [[). interval_index uses interval-first query/pop APIs; sequence front/back/endpoints remain blocked. interval_index point queries use peek_point/pop_point = "first"|"" semantics. Ordered merge remains unavailable currently retained internal merge primitive.

title: immutables
text: immutables R package implements sequence objects (flexseq()) supporting indexed named access, appending prepending, concatenation, splitting, fast push pop either end, item removal, . Also implemented priority queues (priority_queue()) supporting addition min max peeking popping priority value. Backed monoid-annotated 2-3 fingertrees described Hinze Paterson, structures persistent (operations return effective modified copies), operations constant time, amortized constant time, O(log⁡(n))O(\log(n)) (indexing kk elements O(klog⁡(n))O(k \log(n))). Core functions implemented C++ (via Rcpp) speed, parallel R implementations using lambda.r match counterparts paper. developer API supports addition custom structures via combinations monoids measures; see vignettes details. Hinze, R. Paterson, R. (2006), Finger trees: simple general-purpose data structure.

title: Flexseq Indexing — $.flexseq
text: `$`: matched element. `$<-`: updated tree one named element replaced. `[`: new `flexseq` containing selected elements query order.   character indexing, missing names represented `NULL` elements. `[[`: extracted element (internal name metadata removed). `[<-`: new `flexseq` selected elements replaced. `[[<-`: new `flexseq` one element replaced.

title: Flexseq Indexing — $.flexseq
code: # $ extracts by name x <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(1:3), c("a", "b", "c"))) x$b #> [1] 2  # $<- replaces by name x <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(1:3), c("a", "b", "c"))) x$b <- 20 x$b #> [1] 20 x <- as_flexseq(letters[1:6]) x #> FingerTree <size=6, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "a" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "b" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "c" #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] "d" #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] "e" #>  #> [[6]] #> [1] "f" #>   x2 <- x[c(2, 4, 6)] x2 #> FingerTree <size=3, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "b" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "d" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "f" #>   # named lookups return NULL for missing names x3 <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(letters[1:4]), c("w", "x", "y", "z"))) x4 <- x3[c("y", "missing", "w")] x4 #> FingerTree <size=3, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "c" #>  #> [[2]] #> NULL #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "a" #>   # logical indexing supports recycling x[c(TRUE, FALSE)] #> FingerTree <size=3, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "a" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "c" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "e" #>   # [[ extracts one element x <- as_flexseq(letters[1:5]) x[[3]] #> [1] "c"  x2 <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(letters[1:3]), c("a1", "a2", "a3"))) x2[["a2"]] #> [1] "b"  # [<- replaces selected elements x <- as_flexseq(1:6) x #> FingerTree <size=6, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 2 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 3 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 4 #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] 5 #>  #> [[6]] #> [1] 6 #>   x2 <- x x2[c(2, 5)] <- list(20, 50) x2 #> FingerTree <size=6, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 20 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 3 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 4 #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] 50 #>  #> [[6]] #> [1] 6 #>   # character replacement uses element names x3 <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(1:4), c("a", "b", "c", "d"))) x3[c("d", "a")] <- list(40, 10) x3 #> FingerTree <size=4, named=yes> #>   monoids: none #>  #> $a #> [1] 10 #>  #> $b #> [1] 2 #>  #> $c #> [1] 3 #>  #> $d #> [1] 40 #>   # logical replacement supports recycling x4 <- x x4[c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE)] <- list(1) x4 #> FingerTree <size=6, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 2 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 4 #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] 1 #>  #> [[6]] #> [1] 6 #>   # [[<- replaces one element x <- as_flexseq(letters[1:4]) x2 <- x x2[[2]] <- "ZZ" x2 #> FingerTree <size=4, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "a" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "ZZ" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "c" #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] "d" #>   x3 <- as_flexseq(setNames(as.list(1:3), c("x", "y", "z"))) x3[["y"]] <- 99 x3 #> FingerTree <size=3, named=yes> #>   monoids: none #>  #> $x #> [1] 1 #>  #> $y #> [1] 99 #>  #> $z #> [1] 3 #>   # assigning NULL removes one element x4 <- as_flexseq(letters[1:4]) x4[[2]] <- NULL x4 #> FingerTree <size=3, named=no> #>   monoids: none #>  #> [[1]] #> [1] "a" #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] "c" #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] "d" #>
